reading_mnemonic: This word is made up of a single kanji, but it uses the on'yomi reading, not the kun'yomi reading. Luckily, you've learned this reading already. Yay!
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, just rendaku'd.
The reading is the 頃 reading from the kanji reading. Be careful, it's the rendaku'd form.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
The reading comes from 一斉.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
<vocabulary>To serve</vocabulary> you well, we've gotten ourselves <reading>two ca</reading>rs (つか). If one breaks down, we can still serve you with the other car.

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned these, but since 元 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you out:

The <vocabulary>ringleader</vocabulary> of all these problems is <reading>Gen</reading>ji (<ja>げん</ja>). He's the <vocabulary>main culprit</vocabulary> behind this mess. Remember all that trouble he stirred up by flirting with too many women in "The Tale of Genji"? Everyone admired his beauty, but there's no doubt he was the <vocabulary>root cause</vocabulary> of a lot of chaos.
The reading is the kun'yomi vocab readings of the two kanji. That's 先 and 頃 (the reading you learned) put together. The 頃 is the rendaku'd version, ごろ so be careful.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Recognize this word? Na naaa na na na na na na naaa ♬.
The reading is the same as the one you learned in the kanji.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Imagine you're getting married to a valley girl. You're all like. Hey, I'm gonna marry you! And she's all like <reading>Tots</reading> (とつ), we gonna get, like, married! Imagine her saying more "tots" things (tots = short for totally in valley girl speak, at least in my imagination).
The reading comes from 小 (which is a reading you've seen a couple times now, I'm sure) and 包み, with the み pushed inside the package. Beware of the somewhat weird rendaku. You don't see づ too often.
The readings are all ones you've seen before. 小 uses its こ reading, so just think of this like a "child boat." This makes sense because it's small. Watch out for the rendaku.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading is the reading of the vocab version of 年 plus 頃, put together. Note: You will also sometimes see this written partially in kana like 年ごろ.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading comes from 引く and 裂く.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Note this uses the secondary 霊 reading of りょう, so imagine an evil spirit rowing a boat.
The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

If you're going <vocabulary>to rub</vocabulary> me like that, I'm going to <reading>sue</reading> (す) you. It's making me very uncomfortable. The <reading>cos</reading>t  (こす) of your rubbing actions will be high.
    
So this word has two readings and both mean “to rub.” But you usually use する for a single action, such as lighting a match or grazing your knee, while こする means doing it repeatedly, like when you’re cleaning or polishing something.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

When looking at a calendar, the <reading>子読み</reading> (こよみ) of it is to... well... not be able to read it at all. Because, children can't really read. So, when you look at a calendar you have to explain it to a child, since they cannot read it.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. It also happens to be the same as 雲, which has a very similar meaning (clouds).
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the shortening.

meanings.meaning: To Let Someone Stay The Night

reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 泊まる.

allMeanings.meaning: To Let Someone Stay The Night

reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

You know what's really damp and moist? <reading>Shee</reading>p <reading>me</reading>n (しめ) are. They've been hanging out in a greenhouse and now their wool is all damp. They're going to need a towel to dry off.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just be careful of the shortening, and the irregular reading for 気.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

If you step in that <vocabulary>gutter</vocabulary> you'll catch <reading>measle</reading>s (みぞ). A gutter or <vocabulary>ditch</vocabulary> has all kinds of dirt and germs in it, including measles, so don't go stepping in it or drinking from it!
"THE <reading>HORROR</reading>!" (ほろ) you cry, as your beer is about <vocabulary>to be destroyed</vocabulary>.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
The reading is the kun'yomi vocab reading of each kanji: 滝 and 川. Careful of the rendaku.
The reading comes from the individual words, 潮 and 時. Watch out for the rendaku.
You learned this reading when you learned the kanji.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
You're being rude, but you're also being a big <reading>ass</reading> (あせ) with your impatience.

To remember the reading, just think about how when you go crazy, you are <reading>coming</reading> (来る) to crazy town. Just imagine some voice beckoning you to come. Come here! Please come here! Come to crazy town! Give in to the voices!
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading uses the reading from the kanji.

You learned the reading of 狩 when you learned the kanji, but the reading for 人 is totally irregular. Just imagine that you're hunting a reindeer named <reading>Rudo</reading>lph (りゅうど). He has an unusually red nose, which makes him easy to spot and puts him at a bit of a disadvantage.

You didn't learn this reading for 献 with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

I'm actually announcing the <vocabulary>menu</vocabulary> for <reading>con</reading>dors (こん). You thought I was going to tell you what's on the menu for humans? No no, that's a surprise. Condors need a heads-up for these things, because meals are extremely important to condors, given their size and everything.

To learn the reading, just think about how you're looking at something for a lonnnnng time if you're staring at it. In Japanese the word "long" is 長い, and guess what the reading of the kanji part is? It's なが, just like <reading>なが</reading>める's kanji-part reading.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

The person who's holding the <vocabulary>spear</vocabulary> is a little <reading>hoe 子</reading>. It's a child who learned to fight with a hoe, and he's turned the hoe into a <vocabulary>spear</vocabulary> to fight with. Imagine him swinging his hoe spear around like a little dork.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading is the same as a very similar word, 固い. So, if you can use that word to help you to remember, you'll remember the reading of this word in no time as well!
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
<vocabulary>To earn income</vocabulary>, you decided to start a <reading>car</reading> <reading>sa</reading>le. (かせ) "Every car sale, a step to richness!" was your quirky business mantra.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own!
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
You learned this reading already! You should be able to read this too!
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
The readings are the vocab kun'yomi readings of each kanji, 肌 and 色 combined into one.
The reading is 肌 plus 触る's reading, combined. Watch out for the rendaku.
The reading is the same as 足, which also means <vocabulary>leg</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>foot</vocabulary>.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Also the same as 船.
We all know it's not okay to <vocabulary>to torment</vocabulary> each other. So how about we all <reading>sign a</reading> (さいな) contract saying that we'll never torment anyone ever again?
The reading is 若い and 頃 combined into one.

You are <vocabulary>naked</vocabulary> now. You used to wear a car, but you don't have it anymore (and you're not wearing it). You <reading>had a ca</reading>r (はだか), but now you don't have a car. That's what you'll explain when someone asks you why you're naked.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Seeing the <vocabulary>bell</vocabulary>, you decide you need to ring it. You take your <reading>cane</reading> (かね) and hit the bell as hard as you can, making it chime.

Look at a <vocabulary>shadow</vocabulary>. It's long, surprisingly long. It's in the shape of a <reading>cage</reading> (かげ), because that's what is producing the long shadow. Check out each bar of the cage. Maybe you're inside the cage? Whatever is going on, a long shadow is being created by the cage and shade.

The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Bear in mind that it's pronounced ころ when it's a noun, but it's usually ごろ when it's a suffix, though some people say ころ in both cases.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Look inside your <kanji>soul</kanji>. You see all the bits and bobs that make up your <vocabulary>soul</vocabulary> rolling around and around, being pushed by the Katamari <reading>Tamashii</reading> (たましい). He keeps your soul nice and big and safe!
The reading is the individual vocab readings of the two kanji, 鳥 and 肌.
The reading is the kun'yomi readings of the two kanji, put together. 黒 and 潮.
